subject: Business
title: Index Funds: Beating the Experts by Not Trying
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Index Funds: Beating the Experts by Not Trying.

hook.text: Over 15 years, 92% of professional fund managers failed to beat the S&P 500 index. The amateurs won.

buildup.text: An index fund buys every stock in an index (like the S&P 500), matching the market rather than trying to beat it.

discovery.text: Index funds charge tiny fees (0.03%) vs. active funds (1%+). That difference compounds to hundreds of thousands over a.

twist.text: Warren Buffett bet $1 million that an index fund would beat hedge funds over 10 years. The index fund won easily.

climax.text: Vanguard's founder John Bogle created the first index fund in 1976.

punchline.text: Don't pick stocks. Own them all. Let compound growth do the rest.

quiz.question: Why do index funds tend to outperform actively managed funds?
options: Much lower fees compound into significant savings, and most managers can't beat the market
Index funds use secret trading strategies
Index funds only invest in technology companies
